title: 104_hr3738
content: The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 is amended to reduce the extended benefits trigger from 5% to 4%. The effective date for this change is 6 months after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Social Security Act is amended to adjust earnings credited to state accounts based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. The Social Security Act is amended to adjust earnings allocated to state accounts based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. The Social Security Act is amended to adjust state account earnings based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. If a State account exceeds the funding goal, the amount credited will increase by the interest premium on the excess balance. Conversely, if the balance is below the funding goal, the credited amount will decrease by the interest penalty, with a limit of $2,500,000 per quarter. The Social Security Act is amended to adjust state account earnings based on meeting or failing to meet funding goals. If a State account exceeds the funding goal, the amount credited will increase by the interest premium on the excess balance. Conversely, if the balance is below the funding goal, the credited amount will decrease by the interest penalty, with a limit of $2,500,000 per quarter. For any calendar quarter, the adjustment formula is as follows: one-half of one percent of the excess amount for the State with the largest percentage value over the funding goal, and a calculated product for each other State based on their excess balance and percentage value. The Secretary will adjust interest premiums if they exceed interest penalties for a quarter. The term 'interest penalty' is defined for each State based on their excess balance over the funding goal in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The funding goal for a State is calculated based on the average unemployment insurance benefits paid over the highest 3 years in a 20-year period. The percentage value of the excess balance over this funding goal determines adjustments in interest premiums. The excess balance in a State account in the Unemployment Trust Fund determines adjustments in interest premiums. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding amounts credited to state accounts and the interest rate on repayment of advances. Amendments to the Social Security Act involve adjustments in interest premiums based on excess balances in State accounts. A report recommending funding sources for interest premiums under a new section is required within six months of the Act's enactment. The effective date for these amendments is for calendar years starting after December 31, 1996. Amendments to the Social Security Act require states to meet funding goals in their Unemployment Trust Fund to receive interest-free advances. Effective date for these changes is after December 31, 1996. SEC. 4. STATE COLLECTION OF FEDERAL UNEMPLOYMENT TAX. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on state collection of tax. The new section amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow states to collect federal unemployment tax from employers who pay contributions into the state's unemployment fund. Employers can submit the tax to the state instead of the Secretary of Labor, as long as it is paid at the same time as contributions to the state fund. The new section allows states to collect federal unemployment tax from employers who pay contributions into the state's fund. Employers can submit the tax to the state instead of the Secretary of Labor, as long as it is paid on time. States must transmit the tax amount to the Secretary along with employer tax returns. Regulations may require additional information from states regarding the tax payable by employers. The Code is amended by replacing the item for section 3311 with new items. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996. Required distribution of state-specific information packets. SEC. 5. REQUIRED DISTRIBUTION OF STATE-SPECIFIC INFORMATION PACKETS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require states to distribute information packets explaining unemployment insurance eligibility conditions to unemployed individuals. Effective date is for certifications of states for 1997, with a deadline of July 1, 1998 for compliance if the state legislature does not meet in a regular session closing in 1997.
